thread.title: David Davis accused of sexism after denying he tried to kiss Diane Abbott because he is 'not blind'
thread.title_full: David Davis accused of sexism after denying he tried to kiss Diane Abbott because he is 'not blind'

author: Laura Hughes
title: David Davis accused of sexism after denying he tried to kiss Diane Abbott because he is 'not blind'
text:
David Davis accused of sexism after denying he tried to kiss Diane Abbott because he is 'not blind' David Davis Credit: Mark Thomas/REX/Shutterstock Laura Hughes , Political Correspondent  24am 
D avid Davis has found himself at the center of a sexism row after claiming he would never have tried to kiss Diane Abbott because he is "not blind". 
The Brexit Secretary reportedly tried embrace the shadow home secretary in a Commons bar last week after MPs voted overwhelmingly to trigger Article 50. 
It was reported that Ms Abbott told Mr Davis to "f--- off" and rejected his advances. Labour MP Diane Abbott Credit: John Nguyen/JNVisuals 
A fter the incident, Mr Davis exchanged text messages with another Tory MP regarding the incident, according to the Mail on Sunday. 
The newspaper reported that the friend texted Mr Davis, saying: "Cannot believe you made an attempt to give DA (Diane Abbott) a hug!" 
The Cabinet minister replied: "Didn't, but the myth grows. I whispered in her ear, 'Thanks for your vote' - hence the 'F off'. I am not blind." Palace of Westminster Credit: Eddie Mulholland 
T he colleague then wrote: "Ha! Ha! Thank God you aren't blind. Great week for you and Brexit!" 
Then, in an apparent reference to the Specsavers advert in which people with bad eyesight make embarrassing mistakes, Mr Davis texted: "Actually it would make a good Optical Express advert ... Yes, a reasonable success." 
Jess Phillips, a Labour MP, said: "You'd have hoped this sort of misogynistic, sexist attitude had gone out in the 1950s." 
A spokesman for the Brexit Secretary insisted Mr Davis respected Ms Abbott and had been joking, saying: "This was a self-evidently jocular and private exchange with a friend. 
"The Secretary of State is very sorry for any offence caused to Miss Abbott, someone he has known and respected for many years." Follow Telegraph News
